subclassFeature.name: Ring Warden
entries: 矮人们很久以前发现了将魔法注入金属戒指的方法，于是戒指守护者诞生了。以变化学派为重点，他们将矮人的工艺与奥术力量融合在一起。戒指守护者在矮人国家之外很罕见，但由于他们独特的戒指杖，很容易被认出。

subclassFeature.name: Bonded Ring-Staff
entries: 从2级开始，你制作了一个特殊的{@item quarterstaff|PHB}，其中嵌入了两个金属环或固定在上面。你可以将你的戒杖环作为{@item arcane focus|PHB}。制作额外的环需要8小时的工作时间，使用{@item Smith's Tools|PHB|blacksmith's}或{@item jeweler's tools|PHB}，并花费5gp的原材料。你的戒杖可以包含与你的法师等级相等的环数。
当你使用戒指杖施放法术造成伤害时，你可以将你的熟练加值加到结果上。如果法术对多个目标生成多次伤害骰（例如{@spell scorching ray}），你必须在掷骰之前选择哪个骰获得这个加值。你可以使用这个能力的次数等于你的戒指杖上制成的金属戒指数量，最多不超过你的智力调整值（最少为1）。当你完成短休或长休时，你会回复所有已使用的次数。

subclassFeature.name: Bonus Proficiency
entries: 在2级时，你可以选择获得{@item Smith's Tools|PHB|blacksmith's}或{@item jeweler's tools|PHB}的熟练加值。

subclassFeature.name: Transmutation Savant
entries: 从你在2级选择这个传统开始，将复制转化法术到你的法术书中所需的金钱和时间减半。

subclassFeature.name: Master Metalsmith
entries: 从6级开始，你可以在使用你在2级选择的工具时，额外添加双倍的熟练加值。当使用你选择的工具制作日常物品或魔法物品时，你每天的进度是正常的两倍。

此外，你学会了制作一种特定类型的魔法戒指的配方，可以从以下列表中选择：{@item ring of jumping}，{@item ring of mind shielding}，{@item ring of protection}，{@item ring of the ram}，{@item ring of regeneration}，{@item ring of resistance}。在GM的裁量下，你也可以选择不在此列表中的戒指。你必须符合制作该戒指的所有标准先决条件，并按照正常程序支付所需的金币，以及GM设定的任何特殊材料或条件。

subclassFeature.name: Imbue Ring
entries: 从10级开始，你可以将魔法灌注到你的戒杖中嵌入的戒指中。当你施放一个法术时，你可以选择将法术灌注到其中一个戒指中。只要法术被灌注，你就无法恢复已用的法术位。作为一个动作，你可以从戒杖上取下一个被灌注的戒指并将其交给另一个生物（或者自己留着）。持有被灌注戒指的生物可以在一个动作中释放被灌注的法术。攻击检定、豁免检定和伤害都基于灌注戒指的施法者，但持有戒指的生物在所有其他方面被视为法术的施法者。
一个被赋予魔力的戒指在{@spell dispel magic}方面被视为持续施法。你可以同时拥有的被赋予魔力的戒指数量等同于你的熟练加值。

subclassFeature.name: Ring Bond
entries: 在14级时，经过1小时的工作（可以在短休息期间完成），你可以将一枚魔法戒指嵌入你的戒指杖中。只要你握住戒指杖，你就会获得嵌入戒指的效果，就好像你已经调谐并佩戴了它（包括调谐该物品的任何负面效果，比如诅咒）。这枚戒指不算在你的三个调谐魔法物品中。
你可以在1小时的工作中移除一个镶嵌的戒指（以及它的连接），并且你可以同时用一个新的戒指替换它。

feat.name: Circle Spellcaster
entries: 你学会了在你和一个盟友的法术施法者之间建立一个循环的魔法流，以增强你的法术。你获得以下好处。

items: 你可以花费2小时（包括在长休期间）与另一位咒术师建立神秘的联系。你们两人都必须在冥想中度过这段时间，并且你们必须保持在彼此之间不超过10英尺的距离。一旦联系建立，你们可以共同努力增强彼此的魔法。当你们中的一人施放一个需要{@status concentration}的咒语时，另一个可以利用自己的反应来帮助维持这个咒语。如果施法者必须进行一次体质豁免来维持{@status concentration}对这个咒语的影响，你们两人都要进行这次豁免。如果其中一人成功，{@status concentration}就不会中断。如果两次豁免都失败，你们两人将失去{@status concentration}对任何你们当前正在维持的咒语，并且你们都会因为过度使用而受到{@damage 2d6}的精神伤害。你只能同时与一个咒术师保持这种联系。如果你建立了新的联系，之前的联系就会断开。否则，这种联系会持续直到你的下一个长休结束。

feat.name: Ring-Bound
entries: 你获得了一枚被魔法注入的戒指作为尊重的象征。你获得以下好处。

items: 你对转化系法术的豁免检定获得优势。(transmutation spells)
你可以在短休息期间完成的1小时工作中，将你的戒指令牌与武器物理绑定。当戒指连接到武器上时，你可以使用一个奖励动作，使武器在你的下一个回合开始前变为魔法武器。在激活此能力两次后，你必须完成一次短休息或长休息，才能再次使用它。
遵循环戒魔法传统的环卫者和其他尊重这些传统的人对你持有良好态度。他们对你的初始态度自动提升一级，并且你在与这些生物进行社交互动相关的魅力检定中获得优势。

spell.name: Bitter Chains
entries: 你手中的尖刺戒指自我复制成一根长长的带刺链条，以便捕捉你触碰到的生物。对目标进行一次近战法术攻击。命中则目标会被金属链条束缚一段时间。在被束缚期间，目标只能以半速移动，并且在攻击检定、豁免检定和敏捷检定中有劣势。如果目标在一个回合内移动超过5英尺，它会受到{@damage 3d6}来自链条刺的穿刺伤害。
生物可以通过使用一个动作，并对你的法术豁免 DC 进行成功的力量或敏捷检定来摆脱锁链，或者如果锁链被摧毁。锁链的 AC 为 18，有 20 点生命值。

spell.name: Circle of Devastation
entries: 你在你能看到的范围内创建一个半径为20英尺的、高10英尺的毁灭性能量环。环内的区域是艰难地形。当你施放这个法术并在每个你的回合的奖励动作中，你可以选择以下伤害类型之一：冰冷、火焰、闪电、死灵或辐射。接触环的生物和物体，当它被创建时在内部，或者在环内结束他们的回合时，会受到{@damage 6d6}选择类型的伤害，或者在成功的体质豁免检定后受到一半伤害。被该法术降至0生命值的生物或物体会变成细灰。
在你的每个后续回合开始时，戒指的半径会扩大20英尺。任何被扩大的环触碰到的生物或物体立即受到其影响。

spell.name: Circle of Wind
entries: 微风环绕着你，将你置于一个轻微漩涡的中心。你对远程攻击获得+2点AC奖励。你还在对抗{@hazard extreme heat|DMG|extreme environmental heat}和有害气体、蒸汽以及吸入毒素的豁免检定中获得优势。

spell.name: Create Ring Servant
entries: 你触摸两个金属环，并赋予它们生命，创造出一个寿命短暂但有意识的构造体，被称为{@creature ring servant|DM09} {@homebrew |(see "New Monster: Ring Servant")}。
{@creature ring servant|DM09} 出现在你身边。当它的生命值降至 0 点或者法术结束时，它会恢复成用来施放法术的戒指。
在持续时间内，{@creature ring servant|DM09}对你和你的同伴友好。为{@creature ring servant|DM09}投掷先攻检定，它将在自己的回合行动。它会服从你发出的口头命令（你无需采取任何行动）。如果你没有给{@creature ring servant|DM09}下达任何命令，它会保护自己和你免受敌对生物的伤害，但不会采取其他行动。

spell.name: Curse Ring

m.text: 250 gp worth of diamond dust, which the spell consumes

entries: 你对一枚未被佩戴或携带的戒指施加了诅咒。当你施放这个法术时，选择{@spell bestow curse}中的一个可能效果。下一个自愿戴上这枚戒指的生物将遭受选择的效果，无需豁免投。诅咒会在戒指被戴上后从戒指转移到佩戴者身上；戒指变成一枚普通戒指，可以取下，但诅咒仍然留在戴上它的生物身上，直到诅咒被移除或驱散。对被诅咒戒指施放的{@spell identify}法术会揭示它被诅咒的事实。

spell.name: Enchant Ring

m.text: 500 gp worth of diamond dust, which the spell consumes

entries: 你给一枚未被佩戴或携带的戒指施加了魔法。下一个自愿戴上这枚戒指的生物在接下来的1周内，或者直到被你或你的盟友伤害为止，会被你 {@condition charmed}。如果生物在你或你的盟友的直接威胁下戴上戒指，那么咒语会失败。
这个{@condition charmed}生物把你当作朋友。当法术结束时，它并不知道是你施放了法术，但它意识到自己对你的感情在短时间内发生了变化（可能是巨大的）。生物未来如何反应和对待你取决于GM。

spell.name: Hoarfrost

components.m: an iron ring that has been subjected to freezing temperature for at least a day

entries: 你手持的近战武器被注入了深寒之力。在持续时间内，武器表面覆盖着一层霜冻，如果周围环境温度高于冰点，武器上会升起轻微蒸汽。这把武器变成了魔法武器，在成功命中时额外造成{@damage 1d4}点冰冷伤害。如果你再次施放该法术或者放开武器，法术就会结束。
当你达到5级({@dice 2d4})、11级({@dice 3d4})和17级({@dice 4d4})时，该法术的伤害增加了{@dice 1d4}。

spell.name: Innocuous Aspect
entries: 在你周围20英尺范围内，出现了一个虚假视觉的环。你和你选择影响的区域内的每个生物都会呈现出你选择的一种无害生物或物体的外观。每个形象都是相同的，只有视觉受到影响。声音、移动或实际检查可能会揭穿这个幻象。
一只生物可以使用其动作来检查这个影像，通过对你的法术豁免 DC 的成功智力检定（{@skill Investigation}）来确定这是一个幻象。如果一只生物识破了这个幻象，那么它能看穿这个影像。

spell.name: Reverberate
entries: You strike the ground with the metal ring, shaking the earth ahead of you with the impact. Creatures and unattended objects touching the ground in a 15-foot cone emanating from you take {@damage 4d6} thunder damage and fall {@condition prone}; a successful Dexterity saving throw halves the damage and prevents the creature from falling pone.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, the damage increases by {@dice 1d6} for each slot level above 2nd.

spell.name: Ringstrike

m.text: a metal ring for each strike granted by the spell, which the spell consumes

entries: You infuse up to two metal rings with magic, causing them to revolve in a slow orbit around your head or hand. For the duration, when you hit a target within the spell's range with an attack, you can launch one of the rings to strike the target as well. The target takes {@damage 1d10} bludgeoning damage and must succeed on a Strength saving throw or be pushed 5 feet directly away from you. The ring is destroyed when it strikes.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, you can affect up to two additional rings for each spell slot above 1st.

spell.name: Ringward

m.text: an iron ring worth 200 gp, which the spell consumes

entries: This spell causes the iron ring to become a faintly shimmering ring of energy that spins slowly around you at a radius of 15 feet. For the duration, you and your allies inside the protective energy ring have advantage on saving throws against spells and gain resistance to one type of damage of your choice.

spell.name: Spinning Axes
entries: Spinning axes made of luminous force burst out from you in a ring shape, striking all creatures within 10 feet of you. Each creature within 10 feet of you takes {@damage 5d8} force damage, or half damage with a successful Dexterity saving throw. Creatures that aren't undead or constructs and that are damaged by this spell begin bleeding. A bleeding creature takes {@damage 2d6} necrotic damage at the end of its turn. Bleeding can be stopped by using an action to make a successful Wisdom ({@skill Medicine}) check against your spell save DC or by any amount of magical healing or regeneration. Bleeding stops automatically after 1 minute.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 5th level or higher, the damage increases by {@dice 1d8} for each slot level above 4th.

item.name: Karrek's Bastion
entries: Karrek's Bastion resembles a {@item warden's link|DM09}. It's a magical, sentient, adamantine ring 3 inches in diameter, decorated with gold-inlaid runes. When the ring is attached to a nonmagical weapon, the weapon

items: becomes magical with a +3 bonus to attack and damage rolls,
scores a critical hit on a roll of 19 or 20, and
does an additional {@damage 1d10} fire damage per hit, or {@damage 3d10} fire damage to orcs, giants, goblins, and undead.

entries.name: Random Properties
entries: Karrek's Bastion has the following random properties

items: 2 {@table Artifact Properties; Minor Beneficial Properties|dmg|minor beneficial} properties
1 {@table Artifact Properties; Minor Detrimental Properties|dmg|minor detrimental} property
1 {@table Artifact Properties; Major Detrimental Properties|dmg|major detrimental} property

entries.name: Unyielding Spirit
entries: While you carry Karrek's Bastion on your person, you have resistance to necrotic damage, your hit point maximum can't be reduced, and you can't be {@condition frightened}.

entries.name: Spells
entries: While the ring is on your person, you can use an action to cast one of the following spells (save {@dc 18}) from it: {@spell death ward}, {@spell heat metal}, or {@spell stone shape}. Once you use the ring to cast a spell, you can't cast that spell again from it until the next dawn.

entries.name: Sentience
entries: Karrek's Bastion is a sentient, Lawful Good item with Intelligence 14, Wisdom 16, and Charisma 18. It has hearing and {@sense darkvision} out to 120 feet. The item communicates telepathically with its wielder and can speak, read, and understand {@language Common} and {@language Dwarvish}.

entries.name: Personality
entries: The item's purpose is to defend the ring wardens and their allies and to drive back the foes of the dwarves. It is stubborn, brave to a fault, and enjoys humorous wordplay. It urges its wielder to attach it to a {@item maul|PHB} above all other weapons, but it will grudgingly accept any martial weapon. Trying to attach it to a finesse or ranged weapon is sure to cause a personality conflict.
Karrek's Bastion deeply hates anyone who steals or misuses the secrets of ring magic, and it drives its wielder to harry such individuals to their doom and recover the stolen secrets.

entries.name: Destroying Karrek's Bastion
entries: The adamantine ring must be laid on the first of the forges in the halls of the ring wardens, and one ring warden must slay another ring warden with the forge hammer. While the hammer is still soaked with warm blood, it can be used to unmake the ring on the forge.

Karrek was a dwarven warlord in the time when ring wardens were struggling to realize the full potential of their discovery. Without him, the order would have died before it was born. During the nascent ring wardens' trek into the earth to find their home, they ran afoul of a great evil host in the depths. They fought bitterly for every inch of ground but were doomed to be driven out of the molten fire caverns or destroyed utterly.

One of the pilgrims, a clansman of Karrek's, sent word of their plight to the surface stronghold, and Karrek himself answered. He led a force of dwarf shocktroops into the depths and turned the tide of battle. Grievously wounded during the fighting, the stubborn chief waved off more than first aid, refusing to be bedridden while there was work to be done and his people to protect. His wounds worsened and on his death bed, the ring wardens showed him their thanks by offering him the chance to protect his people for all time; they bound his soul into an adamantine ring, where he maintains his vigil still.

item.name: Legendary Molten Fire Forge
entries: This magical furnace and anvil were patterned off the original forges in the deep halls of the ring wardens. Rarely, a molten fire forge is given as a gift to a warlord who champions the cause of the wardens and proves himself an unwavering ally.

A character proficient with {@item smith's tools|PHB|blacksmith's tools} who creates a weapon or armor of sufficient quality using the forge finds his creations imbued with magic. The forge allows for the creation of magic weapons and armor without the need to find a formula. The maximum quality of item produced is very rare. The creator must provide the required gold and makes progress toward completion as normal for crafting a magic item. If the creator doesn't meet the level requirement for the rarity of the item being created, the creator can attempt a Wisdom check with {@item smith's tools|PHB|blacksmith's tools}; the DC = 10, plus 5 for every rarity level above uncommon. If the check succeeds, the item is created successfully. On a failure, the enchantment fails and the gold and time are spent creating a nonmagical, but likely high quality, item.
Any item created with the molten fire forge requires GM approval. The GM may require special components or materials in addition to the normal gold cost.

item.name: Oathbound Ring
entries: This adamantine ring is plain on the outside, but dwarven runes demanding honor and fidelity are inscribed on the inside of the band. The few oathbound rings known to exist were given to nondwarf visitors to the halls of the ring wardens, both to ensure the secrets of ring magic and to protect the wardens' trusted friends.

When you attune to this ring, you willingly swear an oath to an individual or an organization, such as the ring wardens. The oath must be specific about a service you will undertake or some action you will refrain from taking.

While attuned to the ring, you have resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from nonmagical attacks, and you can't voluntarily violate the terms of your oath. If a spell or other effect would force you to violate the oath, that spell or effect fails immediately. In the case of an oath of secrecy, mind-reading powers or effects return no useful information if they seek out the knowledge you are sworn to keep. When a creature directly attempts to prevent you from fulfilling your oath, you have advantage on attack rolls, saving throws, and ability checks made against the creature until it no longer opposes you or it dies. If you die while wearing the ring, spells such as {@spell speak with dead} also automatically fail if the questions asked of your corpse would violate your oath.

Once you are attuned to the ring, you can't voluntarily break that attunement, and the ring can't be removed. The ring is immune to psychic, poison, bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage, has AC 20 with a damage threshold of 30, and 50 hit points.

item.name: Rare Molten Fire Forge
entries: This magical furnace and anvil were patterned off the original forges in the deep halls of the ring wardens. Rarely, a molten fire forge is given as a gift to a warlord who champions the cause of the wardens and proves himself an unwavering ally.

A character proficient with {@item smith's tools|PHB|blacksmith's tools} who creates a weapon or armor of sufficient quality using the forge finds his creations imbued with magic. The forge allows for the creation of magic weapons and armor without the need to find a formula. The maximum quality of item produced is uncommon. The creator must provide the required gold and makes progress toward completion as normal for crafting a magic item. If the creator doesn't meet the level requirement for the rarity of the item being created, the creator can attempt a Wisdom check with {@item smith's tools|PHB|blacksmith's tools}; the DC = 10, plus 5 for every rarity level above uncommon. If the check succeeds, the item is created successfully. On a failure, the enchantment fails and the gold and time are spent creating a nonmagical, but likely high quality, item.
Any item created with the molten fire forge requires GM approval. The GM may require special components or materials in addition to the normal gold cost.

item.name: Very Rare Molten Fire Forge
entries: This magical furnace and anvil were patterned off the original forges in the deep halls of the ring wardens. Rarely, a molten fire forge is given as a gift to a warlord who champions the cause of the wardens and proves himself an unwavering ally.

A character proficient with {@item smith's tools|PHB|blacksmith's tools} who creates a weapon or armor of sufficient quality using the forge finds his creations imbued with magic. The forge allows for the creation of magic weapons and armor without the need to find a formula. The maximum quality of item produced is rare. The creator must provide the required gold and makes progress toward completion as normal for crafting a magic item. If the creator doesn't meet the level requirement for the rarity of the item being created, the creator can attempt a Wisdom check with {@item smith's tools|PHB|blacksmith's tools}; the DC = 10, plus 5 for every rarity level above uncommon. If the check succeeds, the item is created successfully. On a failure, the enchantment fails and the gold and time are spent creating a nonmagical, but likely high quality, item.
Any item created with the molten fire forge requires GM approval. The GM may require special components or materials in addition to the normal gold cost.

item.name: Warden's Link
entries: This metal ring is 3 inches in diameter and adorned with dwarven runes. These rings were created by ring wardens to aid their allies in battle, and each one has a specific enchantment reserved for armor, a shield, or a weapon. The warden's link has a rarity one category higher than the enchantment it bears; for example, a warden's link enchanted to provide the effects of {@item armor of resistance} or a {@item +2 weapon||weapon +2} is very rare.

A warden's link confers magical effects when attached to a nonmagical suit of armor, shield, or weapon. Attaching the ring requires 1 hour of work with appropriate tools ({@item leatherworker's tools|PHB} or {@item smith's tools|PHB|blacksmith's tools}, usually) that can be completed during a short rest. A similar process can remove the ring. While the ring is attached to the correct type of item, the item becomes magical and gains the effects carried by the ring. If the enchantment requires attunement, it can be attuned during the same hour it takes to attach the warden's link by the person doing the work. Someone else must devote a different hour to attuning.
Rumors abound regarding warden's links that confer the effects of legendary or even artifact-power enchantments, but the truth of such stories is no longer known.

itemGroup.name: Molten Fire Forge
entries: This magical furnace and anvil were patterned off the original forges in the deep halls of the ring wardens. Rarely, a molten fire forge is given as a gift to a warlord who champions the cause of the wardens and proves himself an unwavering ally.

A character proficient with {@item smith's tools|PHB|blacksmith's tools} who creates a weapon or armor of sufficient quality using the forge finds his creations imbued with magic. The forge allows for the creation of magic weapons and armor without the need to find a formula. The maximum quality of item produced is one rarity less than that of the forge itself; a rare molten fire forge can produce uncommon items, such as a {@item +1 weapon||weapon +1}, or {@item adamantine armor}, for example. The creator must provide the required gold and makes progress toward completion as normal for crafting a magic item. If the creator doesn't meet the level requirement for the rarity of the item being created, the creator can attempt a Wisdom check with {@item smith's tools|PHB|blacksmith's tools}; the DC = 10, plus 5 for every rarity level above uncommon. If the check succeeds, the item is created successfully. On a failure, the enchantment fails and the gold and time are spent creating a nonmagical, but likely high quality, item.
Any item created with the molten fire forge requires GM approval. The GM may require special components or materials in addition to the normal gold cost.

monster.name: Ring Servant
languages: understands the language of its creator but can't speak

trait.name: Immutable Form
entries: The ring servant is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: The ring servant's slam attacks are magical.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The ring servant makes two slam attacks and uses Ring of Destruction if it is ready.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} +8 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}18 ({@damage 3d8 + 5}) bludgeoning damage. A creature hit by a slam attack must succeed on a {@dc 16} Strength saving throw or fall {@condition prone}.

action.name: Ring of Destruction {@recharge 5}
entries: The ring servant magically generates a spinning ring of energy around itself that lasts until the start of its next turn. While the ring is active, any creature that starts its turn within 5 feet of the ring servant or moves to within 5 feet of it during a turn takes 22 ({@damage 5d8}) force damage, or half damage with a successful {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw.

The head, arms, and torso of this massive figure are composed of metal plates surrounding a core of glowing energy. The whole resembles a vaguely humanoid figure, with two metal rings glowing with runes encircling its fists.

Ring servants are mighty constructs created by ring magic. Though large in stature, they are deceptively light because most of their form is composed of energy. A ring servant stands 10 feet tall and weighs 300 pounds.

entries.name: Fleeting Form
entries: Ring servants are temporary beings, brought into existence by transmuting two simple metal rings into the weapons that surmount the creature's fists. These rings serve as the catalyst that generates the rest of the thing's form. Ring servants aren't mindless. They understand the fleeting span of their existence and don't rebel against it. Exceptions exists, where powerful ring wardens work tirelessly to imbue a ring servant with permanent existence. Such an enduring transformation is rare, however, and the resulting creature may have difficulty coming to terms with lingering in the world.

entries.name: Constructed Nature
entries: A ring servant doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

data.name: Ring Magic
entries: Dwarves are renowned shapers of the physical world. Earth, stone, and even metal bend to the will of dwarven hammers. It's easy to assume that because dwarves have such tremendous skill at shaping material, they must lack the time and interest to become masters of the arcane, too—but that assumption is dead wrong. Taking unformed matter and shaping it minutely to conform to one's will is the perfect arena for blending the physical and arcane arts. The dwarves' greatest magic has been bound to this arena, as evidenced by the legendary weapons, armor, and implements of war that emerge from their mountain stronghold forges. Comparatively few dwarves pursue the study of magic outside the act of creation or of devotion to their deities, but one discipline bridges the gap between creation and spellcasting: ring magic.

Ring magic is the dwarven art of forging metal into rings, usually with powerful runes inscribed on their surface, and using those rings to shape magic. Practitioners channel their magic through specially prepared rings, increasing the devastation wreaked upon their foes, and they can even imbue spells into a ring that someone else can unleash later.

Rings created for this purpose are more than decorative jewelry. They more often take the form of precious-metal rings large enough to adorn a weapon, a staff, or a suit of armor. Wizards who devote themselves to ring magic are rare outside dwarf lands, but they're instantly recognizable by the ring-adorned staves they carry.

entries.name: Linking Magic and the Material
entries: The ring is a strange shape to the dwarven mindset, which is firmly rooted in the angles and planes they see constantly in the mineral formations around their underground homes. Dwarf architecture is filled with corners, precise angles, saw-toothed runes, patterns of regular and irregular polygons, adornments of gold laid out in precise geometric forms, and stacked blocks or slabs. These aren't just cultural fashions; such shapes reflect how dwarves think and how they prefer to see the world. Curves are seldom seen, and a circle—devoid of angles and planes, with no beginning and no end—is a foreign shape that denies boundaries and evokes eternity. It is a construct of the mind and spirit but not the chisel; it evokes the sun and moon, raindrops, flowers, and the cycle of the seasons—things that are seen on the surface world but have no place in the hard, subterranean realm of the dwarves. Dwarves make sense of this alien concept by shaping metal into its likeness. Once they can hold this ephemeral concept in their calloused hands, feel its weight and heft, they can better understand.
Yet because it has no beginning and no end, because of its powerful symbolic ties to life, the ring is uniquely suited to be a receptacle for magic.

The first practitioners of ring magic gleaned the secrets from visions granted by their gods. The seeds of ring magic were subtle, woven in dreamlike metaphor that was lost on many but needed the dwarves' mastery of craftsmanship to reach fruition. For generations, it was practiced in such isolation that no one recognized ring magic as a growing craft. Over time the dwarves realized that within their longheld techniques, the ore of another secret awaited excavation. These enlightened dwarves retreated deep under the mountains, to a place where molten rock flowed freely. There they carved great halls and forges fueled by the earth's fire. They worked tirelessly in their delve to perfect their new art, and their efforts were rewarded.

Runes and sigils decorate every inch of this legendary stronghold's walls, revealing the secrets of ring magic and its signature spells to those who can read them. Ring wardens understand these writings as well as if they were their own spellbooks. In fact, a gathering of wizards at the walls, preparing their spells to the sound of ringing hammers, is a common scene. But this is a secretive community. The number of outsiders who have seen the halls of the ring wardens can be counted on one hand, and those few are bound to secrecy by oaths sworn on adamantine rings they can never remove. The molten fire forges still ring under dwarven hammers to this day. While it isn't a requirement to study here for a wizard to become a ring warden, it is a pilgrimage all dwarf ring wardens make at least once.

entries.name: Ring Magic Feats
entries: The following new feats offer options for any character to touch the power of ring magic. At the GM's discretion, a spellcaster who possesses a ring magic feat can learn ring magic spells without finding them in written form.

entries.name: Ring magic in Midgard
entries: In the Midgard Campaign Setting, ring magic is the province of the reaver dwarves of the Northlands. Reaver sorcerers and wizards imbue metal rings with their spells and give the rings to their comrades to unleash in battle. Even in Midgard, ring wardens are rare outside their home culture, and they can easily become the object of fear when they're encountered by outsiders who aren't familiar with ring magic. All dwellers in the Northlands, however, know the tales of the ring-bedecked dwarves marauding from their longships.

The seat of these ring wardens is hidden deep beneath the northern mountains of Midgard. This delving, known as the Foundry of the Fathers, is where the reaver ring wardens craft the rings that are the root of their magic and contemplate the secrets the rings still hold.

entries.name: Ring Magic Items
entries: Ring wardens and other spellcasters who discovered the secrets of ring magic created these magic items. If your campaign utilizes the magic item creation rules, the formulae for ring magic items are esoteric, similar to ring magic spells. They require the creator to be a ring warden, to possess a ring magic feat, or to discover written instructions detailing the ring magic processes used in their creation. These instructions are separate from the formula itself.

entries.name: Ring Magic Artifact
entries: Artifacts are always shrouded in the mists of time and legend. If the GM decides that the rumors surrounding ring magic artifacts are true, here is one possible example of such a powerful and storied item.
